Ulster University celebrates
Coleraine at 50

This is a lead paragraph has been the industry's standard dummy text ever since the 1500s

Lorem Ipsum has been the industry's standard dummy text ever since the 1500s, when an unknown printer took a galley of type and scrambled it to make a type specimen book. It has survived not only five centuries, but also the leap into electronic typesetting, remaining essentially unchanged.

50 title or strapline



Coleraine through the decades



1970-1980


  • 1977 – The Queen visits the Coleraine campus where she holds her Garden Party
  • 1976 – The Riverside Theatre is established in 1976 and, upon completion, wins ‘Design of the Year’.
  • Garfield Weston Trust funds the new University of Ulster to carry out charitable activities for the promotion of education and research.

1980-1990


  • The University merges with the Ulster Polytechnic in Jordanstown to become the University of Ulster.

1990-2000


  • 1997 – The Queen visits Coleraine campus for a second time.

2000-2010


  • 2010 – Dr James Nesbitt becomes Chancellor of the University.

2010-2020


  • 2014 – International experts independently judge the University as one of the top universities in the UK for delivering world-leading research that has a positive and long-term impact on societies and economies globally (REF).
  • University of Ulster is rebranded to Ulster University.
  • New media centre is established at Coleraine campus and includes the largest newsroom in Northern Ireland with a capacity for up to 60 people.
  • New £5 million sports centre is opened on campus.
  • 2015 – The Harry Gregg Foundation is established. In 2017, the Foundation, in partnership with Ulster University, announces £10,000 of sports scholarships to help students from the North Coast area develop their skills both on and off the football pitch.
  • 2015 – Work is completed on the new £5.1 million, three-storey teaching block at Coleraine.

Title and Name

Role
Ulster University

Professor Tara Moore

Personalised medicine for genetic eye disease.

Ulster’s leading-edge ophthalmology research is pioneering personalised medicine for eye disease. We will be showcasing the first and only commercially available genetic testing system for corneal health.

The symptoms of Corneal Dystrophy, which can include vision loss and eye pain, can start as early as the first decade of life or may not show up until the late 50s or 60s, and can be mild, moderate or severe.

This simple DNA test involves a straighforward cheek swab that takes under 30 seconds to complete. Sample collection is quick, painless, reliable and secure – proven to be 100% sensitive and 100% specific in clinical trials – and is currently available in over 50 countries worldwide through Avellino Labs. Partner diagnostics in the form of state-of-the-art CRISPR Cas9 gene editing is currently been developed in collaboration with our researchers.

Professor Tara Moore

Research Director - Biomedical Sciences
Ulster University

Professor James McLaughlin

Research Director – Electrical & Electronic Engineering, Metallurgy & Materials
Ulster University

Professor James McLaughlin

Intelligent, wearable vital signs monitoring

Working in collaboration with Ulster University’s Nanotechnology and Integrated Bioengineering Centre (NIBEC) – an internationally recognised world-class research facility - Intelesens, originally founded as a spin out of Ulster University, specialises in the development of proprietary world class algorithms for the detection of a range of cardiac arrhythmias from wireless sensors on the body.

Ulster will be featuring this technology at the GREAT Festival and how it is destined to make huge strides towards providing cost-effective tools to improve the delivery of cardiovascular care globally.
